response.message:
Hey, where's the link to that "awesome speech" Joel mentions in 34:40?

Thx!
Can't help but get excited when I hear about the new direction that Stack Exchange is taking. Congratulations again to Robert -- nice debut, too!

Jeff, take a look at lensfail.com, a SE site. The site started out well on a great topic - anything and everything related to photography. The site is now rotting (literally) due to most of the reasons that SE 2.0 is going to cure:

  * Not enough founding members
  * Not enough marketing
  * No real commitment

Which, of course leads to:

  * Loss of interest from owners/moderators

Its now (literally) gathering mold in the form of SPAM (possibly even deliberately) and its really sad. It could have been a fantastic resource in a sea of forums that offer (quite often) bad information.

I'm really interested in seeing SE 2.0 launch, it really sounds like you fixed it.
Oh, yeah, I for one welcome our new SysOp community overlord. I think most of us over the age of 30 ran (or at least used) a dial up BBS. I still use several telnet boards.

Gelu -- I forgot to link that "TED speech"

Maybe this one?

http://www.ted.com/talks/dan_pink_on_motivation.html

I'll ask Joel and see if that is the one

Is the meta.stackexchange list of proposed sites real or is it just a mockup?

It's rejecting my SO openid.
Joel pondered whether to mention the real name of the person who proposed the law SE site. Then he did because he said it was public. Where is the name published? I searched the meta site.

SE itself needs more marketing. I asked a few people who know StackOverflow if they heard of stackexchange and they didn't!! Maybe SO needs some SE banner ads.

SE needs to get more people to propose new sites and to get more supporters for these ideas. Otherwise it will just have  very few sites.

>lensfail.com
The problem with lensfail is that there is already a very good site dpreview.com which not only hosts 100s of forums but also has reviews of cameras and real paid journalists attending trade shows, talking to manufacturers and receiving real review hardware.

The problem with the new not-for-profit (or rather all-profit-to-us) stackexchange is that it doesn't work for professional sites.

@ Tim

Lets not sell ourselves short on the years lived - That age group for BBSs is rapidly approaching 40...

You may hate to hear this, but the podcast was actually more valuable to me than the site. In an effort to always improve my code I was learning more from the discussions. 

Needless to say, SO solves specific problems which is very helpful, but the other side of honing the craft requires the conversation aspect.

Regardless, thanks for all the food for thought you have already given us :)
Is there any way we can get a zip file of all the podcasts?
